chapters.golden-age:
Sand covers the floor of a lifeless studio. Organ pipes line the walls. Echo, a bit old for a dancer, waits in the center. 
Patterns of vibrating particles take form before her eyes. The spotlight strikes. She squints through budding wrinkles. Her eyes track the moving floor. Pipes erupt with flame. She holds. Her eyes lift, ready. 
The draw of a bow pulls her into motion. She moves with fluid elegance, like the sand and flame. A bell tolls. She drops in. This is her space. This is her bliss. Overflowing with life, her timeless movements are one with the dancing elements. 
A half-silvered mirror catches her eye: a bell grips her heart and pulls her to her knees. Aquariums shatter. Water soaks the sand.
Shaken, she looks up at the mirror: nothing, no one—only herself. The strap of her shirt has fallen over her shoulder. She feels exposed. Unsafety floods her senses. She hides the adrenaline and defends herself with poise. Placing a hand on her chest, she settles, then stands. 
Echo yells, inaudibly, “It’s too loud.”
Nothing. Concerned, uncertain, pissed—she exhales. The space she was in is inaccessible. She dances anyway. 
The beat hardens. She dances harder to meet it. It gets louder, harder. She re-finds the pocket. Defiant, triumphant, she dances. Wet sand takes form, into dancing bodies, lifting with the music, and taking shape with her. 
The bell tolls again: her heart bursts. She falls, eyes gasping. 
The room quiets. She lies loose. Darkness.
The room strobes, her body convulses—like a puppet.

Six Hours Earlier, at her tower house—a small yellow flower grows from a crack in the curb at the apex of a cul-de-sac. A black caterpillar chews dead grass at the base of a (rusting) golden mailbox. Jaq, twenty-eight, bright, soft, kind, spills from the tower-topped right-hemisphere of her yellow duplex. 
She opens the mail. It spills to the ground. She pans for gold: Water Bill, Jury Bill, Trash, Rental Insurance … Alma Pater University. She rushes inside. 
Jaq enters the duplex. She sets the mail beside a picture of her and Echo in a field of narcissus (daffodils). Jaq wears gold and has golden hair. Echo is darker, raven hair and carbon clothes. 
Jaq closes the door to her bedroom, sits down on the bed. Her room is immaculate besides corners of paper and clothes bursting from her drawers and closet. 
She stares at the golden envelope for a moment, starts to open it, gets nervous, jumps under her covers, pulls up her hood, stares at it again, then, to avoid making a rip, pulls at the tab. It rips. She pulls. 
Tears gather like dew before sunrise. A smile blossoms. She turns the page. Her joy wilts. 
Echo opens the door and leans in, “I booked something!” she says. 
Jaq tries to compose herself with a sniffle. “That’s great. What is it?”
Echo enters the room. “I think it’s some kind of music video.” She notices the crying. “What’s up with you? You doing ok?”
“Couldn’t be happier.”
Echo sits next to her on the bed, looks at Jaq, sees its bad, gets under the covers. “Are you sure?”
“Yeah” She breaks into a cry. “I got into school.”
“The wizard school!?”
Jaq nods. 
“You must be so excited! What’s wrong? Isn’t it what you always wanted?”
Jaq hands her the papers. Echo looks over them. She sighs — in pain with her sister. “Love you.” Jaq sobs. 
“Why does it have to be so expensive? There’s something wrong with our world. You shouldn’t have to feed a broken system just to learn. Maybe this, maybe this just wasn’t the way.”  
Defeated, “Apparently it wasn’t.”
“Can’t you just go out into the world and learn what you want? I don’t understand—what is it about mythology?”
“Myths are spells! We’re all under a thousand spells. Myths are lies, and I want out. I don’t want to be under any spells anymore, but I don’t even know what they are.”
“I thought you wanted to be a storyteller?”
Jaq winces. 
“Sis, this letter is a gift. It’s saving you from years of distraction.”
Jaq takes a deep breath and sighs. 
“I’m not ready.”
“How do you know? 
“I know because my dreams are still better than anything I could ever write, and every time I try, an inner voice just starts laughing at me, like all I’ll ever write is a dream within a dream I can’t even understand.”
“Sis, (laughs), you are so intense. What if writing is your way out?”
“I need training! I need mentors. There are lineages.”
Echo prepares to agree before Jaq takes a swipe. “Besides, you just think I’m in a hurry, because you are a thirty-something-year-old dancer.” 
Echo recoils as though stabbed. Jaq squints with regret. Echo stands from the bed and turns to Jaq.
“Look, I know you are hurting, and I know you feel insecure about yourself and that you take swipes at people when you want to push them out of your business, but it’s mean, Jaq, it’s the worst, and it hurts the people who love you most.”
“Sis…”
The door slams. Jaq curls into an anxious hole in her stomach. 

A little later, the phone rings. Jaq lifts it to her ear, teary. It’s Anteros. “Hi! How are you?” 
“Can you meet me at our spot?”
“What happened? I’ll be right there.”
“Thank you.” 
She hangs up. 

She drives across town. Cars cross this way and that through endless freeways. 

Anteros finds her with artificial blossoms, on artificial turf, under an artificial tree, in dry tears. He sits down next to her, sees the letters, picks them up, sighs, puts his arm around her, kisses her head, thinks. A moment passes. 
“I have an idea.”
“What?” She asks
“Why don’t we go on a mythic adventure? I can work from anywhere. They pay me a ton. Let’s see the world. You can teach me stuff.”
She cries. 
“I can’t.”
“Why not?”
She sobs. 
“Because I don’t love you.”
Anteros smiles and laughs it off with experience. “Oh yeah?”
“You’re amazing and everything I am supposed to want, I just, it’s all chemistry and synapses that put me under a spell. I don’t believe in love. It’s all just sex and trauma bonding and dumb bodies telling our weak brains what to think with their stupid feelings.”
He holds her tighter. Her body loves him. 
He’s amused. “You really don’t believe in love?”
“How could anybody? We are just dead matter under the illusion of consciousness. Nothing is anything but a bunch of stuff bouncing off stuff making bodies, and our bodies just want to mate, and eat.”
“Jaq…”
“I don’t want to mate and eat! I want to know. And when I’m in your spell, I don’t think I can know anything. I get lost. I get scared.”
“Jacqueline, if there is a spell, it’s spun from your enchantments. If I traveled the world with you, I’d be in your web forever — learning mythology, maybe, sounds great, but losing myself.”
“I’m sorry about the school. I love you, and I just want you to be happy. He hugs her. “And can I tell you something?”
She draws back to look in his eyes. 
“I think you love me too.”
She pushes him away. “NO! Tero! I am telling you: I do not believe in love, so I cannot be in love with you.”
He tries to smile. “Jaq, I think you are living proof that someone can love without believing.”
“You are so naïve!” She smiles, “or such a good liar!”
“What do you mean?”
“How do you always say the right thing? The big, loving, caring thing? And then expect me to really believe you’re so pure. No one is that pure! Sometimes I wonder if any of it’s real at all!”
He’s heartbroken, sullen. “Do you really not see my care and my words as love?
Jaq winces at herself, then continues anyway. “Every belief is based on another belief is based on another belief, and I haven’t examined any of them.” She starts crying, fogged over with doubt. “I don’t know. I don’t know anything. How can I know. There is no knowing.” 
Anteros stands from the base of the tree, dejected, looks at her once, then walks away. 

Jaq sits in the waiting room of a hospital. She looks at her black phone. It buzzes. She unlocks it and reads a text from Echo: I’m mad at you. A string of unanswered apologies ascend the screen. But you’re still my emergency contact. And the audition is at a home address. 66 Deadwood. I want you to have it. 
Jaq starts to type a response when the nurse announces, “Jaqueline Stone, he can see you now.” 
Jaq gets up to follow the nurse. I’ve got you, remains unsent. 

She enters the the hospital room. Adam, a stern but sick man in his sixties who seems much older, motions for her to sit. She asks, “How are you?”
“I am how I am.”
Jaq sits. 
“What’s on your mind, Jaq?”
“Why am I so mean to my sister? I hate myself for it. I don’t know where it comes from.”
“You treat her the way you treat the part of yourself just like her.”
“And how do I treat the part of myself that’s like her?”
“You know the answer to that question. You might not have before. I think you do now. I think you have begun to realize what you repress.”
“You think I should be more like her? What, am I supposed to party all night and try every drug and kink and new toxic person?”
“She’s chasing her dream, Jaq, every day, while you run from yours.”
“The long road isn’t running away.”
“You’re ready.”
“I’m not ready.”
“You’re ready, and you know how I know?”
She hangs on his answer. 
“Because you are triggered by the people around you trying to answer their own callings.”
“Ok… What do you even think I’m ready for? I don’t understand. Why didn’t you write me a letter of recommendation? I know you knew they would give me no money. You could have said something!”
He sits back in his hospital bed. “You know I can’t do that. We are only allowed one relationship. We have had this conversation. You are a gifted poet. Go find your education. The world won’t give you anything.”
She takes it in. A nurse enters and sets down his breakfast: olives, dates, apples, white bread and quince jelly.
“I told my boyfriend I don’t love him.” Adam exhales. “Am I crazy?”
“Love serves the perpetuation and evolution of our species. We have selected for it. As a result, we have conditioned ourselves in countless ways to believe in love. You want to be a mythologist and a writer, you should know: myths are lies, and love is the ultimate myth. You only want to love, because your dream says you should—a dream reinforced by the body’s desire.”
“Then you don’t believe in love?”
“The question is not whether or not love is real, Jaq. The question is what love is.” He takes a bite of his stone fruit.
“What is love?
He swallows. “Love is a complex. When we find a relationship in which we unconsciously recognize all our past relationships, and when this person represents the parts of ourselves we want to integrate, in the future, lust looses the arrow of Cupid.”
“Oh.” A thousand connections pour through. 
“Your complex is patterned by your atheism, and by an imprint of the paternal love god you’ve killed. I don’t need to know more detail. I can see from a thousand miles away: you are drawn to men with paternal qualities in whom you see the god of love, who you then doubt, and this will destroy them, which will destroy you. This is your tragedy.” 
Jaq starts to speak. He cuts her off. 
“The only way out, is to see through love. Detach from it. Be a free individual. Love will try to take you over, if you let it, but remember, it’s not real. Everything is separate. The difference about you, Jaq, is you question the spells.”
chapters.falling-star:
Jaq wakes up… 
Washes her face in the bathroom mirror—and tightens a yellow robe. “Hey Sis, how was the audition?”
She asks the air, leaning into the hallway. “Sorry, I couldn’t hear you. Washing my face. What did you say?” 
Nothing. Jaq remembers. She panics—draws out her phone. I’ve got you, remains unsent. No texts from her sister. Her hair raises. She runs for… 

Echo’s Room. The bed is empty, unmade, covered in unchosen clothing. 
She texts her sister. It won’t send. She calls: Voicemail, “This is Echo. Leave a message.”
Nervous, “Hey, Sis, just checking in on you. Give me a call.” She sits on her sister’s bed.
She calls someone else. “Hey, have you heard from Echo?” She looks out the window. ”Oh, ok, no, no, just trying to get ahold of her, thanks.”
She makes another call, eyes fixed on a tidy closet. “Hey, is this Echo’s agent?”
“Echo? Echo Stone? Of course! My darkest star. What’s the project?”
“Actually, I’m her sister, Jaq, and she didn’t come home last night. She went to an audition…”
“What audition?”
“You didn’t send her to…” she looks at her text, “…66 Deadwood?”
“I told her!”
“Told her what? I don’t understand!”
“Ask the police! My clients keep taking these calls, against my advice, and it’s the last I ever hear from them.”
Jaq shivers. 
“Don’t call me.”

In her bedroom, swallowed by covers, Jaq lays by her phone. “Hello, Officer, my sister is missing. She went to an audition last night, and I haven’t heard from her since. It was at a house. She gave me an address, but...”
“What is your name?”
“Jaqueline Stone”
“Age”
“28”
“Marital status?”
She pauses, “Single”
“Are you a gun owner?”
“Excuse me, what does this have to do with my missing sister?”
“Ma’am, it’s just part of the form.”
“No! I am not a gun owner.”
Five minutes later, the Officer finally asks, “Now, what was that address?”
“66 Deadwood.”
“Oh! 66 Deadwood. I’m sorry ma’am, we get this call. Your sister is not on the premises.”
“What are you talking about?”
“We have closed our investigation into this location.”
“Investigation? What are you talking about?”
“The place has been searched. It’s a school.”
“Are there students there?”
“Not anymore.”
“Where are the students?”
“Chasing their dreams. None of them come home.”
Jaq is deflated, unsure. “So you won’t send anyone?”
“We’ve been there, miss. Everything is perfectly normal. If your sister didn’t say goodbye, consider it personal.”
A falling star lights her face—the whole room. His phone clicks. The meteor thunders—into the ground outside her window. 

Jaq opens the door to her front yard. Her drought-gold lawn has been turned over, as though plowed. A meteorite, the size of an arrowhead, glows from the center of a large crater. It cools. The starlight fades. She picks it up. Before she can look, she sees her mailbox, pure shrapnel, at her feet—a broken flag, a gold leaf letter. 
She puts the meteor in her purse and picks up the envelope: It’s to her, from 66 Deadwood. On the back she finds one black spot. 
In her room, on her phone. “I’m freaking out.”
“We’ll find her. I’m sure it will all be ok.”
“It’s not just that.”
“What is it?”
“You’re not going to believe me.”
“What?”
“You know the address she scent?”
“66 Deadwood? It’s unforgettable.”
“I got a letter—from 66 Deadwood.”
“What?! What the fuck does it say?”
Jaq looks at the gold leaf letter. “It says it’s an invitation.”
“To what?”
“An initiation.”
“In what?!”
“Myth and story.” 
“Whaaaattttt is going on!? That is not real. This is some kind of devil shit. You need to call a priest.”
“Nin! This is serious!”
“Do you think your sister got this letter?”
“I do.”
“What else do you think?”
She looks at the shining page. “I think… it’s all I ever wanted. I think there’s no way it’s real. I think I need to find my sister.”
“Shouldn’t the police send someone?”
“They wont. I talked with them.”
“What about Anteros?”
“I can’t ask him.”
“Why not?”
“We had a fight yesterday.”
“What did you do?”
“I told him I don’t love him.”
“You did not!”
“I did.”
“Why did you do that?”
“I just, I don’t know. I doubt sometimes.”
“Is it like a too-perfect kind of thing? I can never trust too perfect. It always feels like there’s something…hiding.”
“That’s what I’m saying! But whatever. I have to go look for my sister.”
“At the house?! Without Tero or the police? Are you crazy? Tell me you’re not curious!” 
“Of course not! I mean, maybe, a little, but I’m curious about everything.”
“Jaq, you know I love you, but I don’t think this is a good idea.”
“I know. But it’s my sister, and she’s missing.”
Nin gets serious. “Yeah. Do you want me to come with?”
“No. Thank you. I want you to be on the phone. And if I’m gone for too long, I want you to get help.” 
Jaq looks at her watch. It’s getting late. She looks at the envelope.
chapters.impact-crater:
She drives, through tunnels of Autumn leaves—golden boughs, at the golden hour, in a golden dress. 
 
A mansion of brick, the soon-setting sun looks down on the world below. She arrives at dusk. Cars line the driveway. Jammed between statues of pebble: Cupid, satyrs, wolves and dragons find shade under petrified trees. She parks, puts in her earbuds, calls Nin and asks, “Are you there?”
“I’m here…”
“What do you see?”
“A lot of people—a long line on a brick path. This place is a mansion.”
“Like a haunted house?”
“Nin!”
“Sorry.”
Jaq takes a breath to settle herself. It doesn’t work. She leaves her car, looks at the house, begins her approach. “Stay on the phone, I’m gonna talk with someone.” 
She taps on the nearest shoulder. “Excuse me, can you please tell me what you’re here for?”
“I have been called to purify my warrior spirit. I am to become a great hero.” 
Jaq nods and backs away, “Oh. Okayyy.”
She looks down at the brick path—a mosaic of golden camels. A bit further up the cue, she taps another shoulder. “Hello, can you tell me why you’re here?” 
A young man in fine clothes leans in to answer, “The secret to success, (according to my insiders) is in this house.” 
“Are you here to become a solider?”
“Do I look like a pawn to you?! Or a sucker!? Success is success. You know what success is—to be rich and powerful.”
“And the secret is in there?” She looks at the house, leery. 
“The secret of pure power and incorruptible will.”
Jaq backs away from the crazy. “Thank you.” She moves on. 
Nin asks, “What the hell was that?!”
“I don’t know man.” 
Shadow hooks her eye—through a gate and around the house. She follows. “I’m going around the side.”
She opens the gate. 

In the Mythouse Garden everything is wasting. The shell-stone fountain in the center is dry as a dead man’s navel—cracked. She sees a door to the house. 
It’s unlocked. “I’m going in.”
“Are you sure?”
“Of course not.” She enters. 

The Halls draw her fear and enchantment: red velvet curtains, black and white tile, paintings, sculptures, statuettes—modern styles and ancient aesthetics. “It’s pretty in here.” Nothing. “Are you there?” Nothing. “Shit.” She puts the earbuds in her purse. 
Glass cases, figurines—worldly, historical—Shadow darts by. She chases. 
It disappears behind a shelf. She nears. She sees a small coffin—no larger than her hand. She looks closer. It’s shaped like a woman’s body—wings wrapped around her womb. Jaq turns the lid, like the cover of a book: an adze, a copper Was scepter, the size of a key. She picks it up. 
Shadow hooks her eye, again. She follows it down the hall, to a door. She approaches: it’s red. She looks at the keyhole. She looks at the adze. It fits. Her heart beats faster. She opens the door and enters… 
The Salon, puts the key in her purse and takes in the space: calendars, globes, circular maps, wheels and books—just one long shelf. 
From left to right, they read: Descent of the Goddess, Book of the Dead, Riddle of the Sphinx, Hymn to Demeter, Allegory of the Cave, Golden Bough, Three Metamorphosis, Night Sea Journey, Rites of Passage, Ways of Initiation, Alice in Wonderland, Individuation, Wizard of Oz, Eternal Return, Hero with a Thousand Faces, Star Wars, Heroine’s Journey, Writers’ Journey, Save the Cat, Nekyia, Hero with an African Face, Transformational Arc, Story Circle, Heroine of 1001 Faces, Collective Journey, and, stuffed into the shelf, on top of the books, she sees a worn folder. All the shadows in the room, including her own and the figure she followed, are drawn, into its folds—like a genie to a lamp. 
Music fills the space. Everything vibrates. She takes the loose folder. It reads, in marker, Story Atlas & the Golden Wheels. She opens it. Red pen, a work-in-progress. 
Music crescendoes. She snaps out of it, puts the manuscript in her purse, and exits to …
The Hall. Young women approach, like a gander of geese, almost dancing, oddly. Their skin is glossy, but matte, like candy wrappers. Their bodies are too plastic, like dolls, their eyes too clear, like diamonds. Jaq, friendly as can be, tries to make contact. 
“Oh my god, hi! Can I ask you a question?” 
The music changes, so do the women. The sound of strings makes them move, like cymatic-puppets. Jaq spools with fear and runs. 
They chase. She struggles to flee in her heels. The hallway fills with dancers. She picks off her shoes, running, hopping, and puts them in her purse. 
At the end of the tunnel, she sees a red door of red windows. A wedge holds it open. She grasps the knob, an apple, kicks the wedge free, slams the door shut and crosses the threshold. 
Jaq enters the studio. Dancers pound the door. She backs away and scans the room: organ pipes, a desert floor, a silvered mirror, a lifeless woman. 
Sound fills the space. Forms vibrate in the sand. A mandala shapes around the woman. Percussion lifts her chest. 
The door bursts open. Puppets pour through, like the sand of an hourglass, their bodies in states of masked decay. Jaq panics. She scans the room. Shadow shoots from her purse—to the doors of a storm shelter. Jaq follows. 
Chased by the zombie chorus, she opens the shelter doors. The hoard swarms. She turns her gaze to the the great below. Darkness. She withdraws to retreat. It’s too late. Bowled over—overwhelmed—they fall, down. 

Sun Sets outside the Mythouse. 

A stair squarcase spirals inward, constricting the dancers, swallowing Jaq. They fall, into infinite regression, into abyss. The staircase becomes a vortex. The vortex becomes a liquid. She’s sucked through the eye. 
The hurricane becomes a cyclone, becomes a spout, becomes spray: the snort of a sperm whale, a spinning platform of water droplets. She yawns, uncontrollably, and descends, towards waiting jaws. The mouth becomes a crack in earth. She’s eaten. 
She comes through a tunnel, through a cavernous opening. Two holes wait beneath her. She falls at the ground between. She screams an inaudible scream, then divides, like a cell—in two—and falls through the slits. 
On the other side, as though she’s passed through a prism, she sees herself in refraction, a rainbow of selves, translucent, wave-like, shimmering. Ripe fruit falls, like rain, all around her split forms. Awe displaces fear. She reaches for an apple. It turns gold to the touch. She snaps to a single body. 
She opens her hand. Inside is a walnut—shaped like a coffin. It carries a seed. Thousands fall, like splinters, to the earth. She falls asleep. 

Black. 

In river caves, in a Gondola, Jaq comes to. It’s dim. She looks behind her. Zombie women, stuck at the bank, look in their own reflections. Beautiful women—Barbie perfect—stare back. One of the girls, deep in her own enchantment, falls into the water. A storm begins to stir. 
Jaq’s pilot, the boatman, Set, wears the robe of Death—black, hooded. He parts the way with his long was scepter. The water is dark. It darkens. He rasps, “Life is abandoned, here, why can you see?”
Jaq observes her surroundings. It’s black as night. “I, I can’t see anything.” She hears the water, his pole. “Everything is dark, like the earth underground… like a grave… like the inside of a jar.” 
Glowing bubbles rise from below. Set’s eyes—empty, black—reflect their hope. “You see. You will believe.”

On a golden island, under heavy rain, Golden Apples shine like little suns and fall. The hood of a cobra protects Jaq. She lies, sleeping, balled, in a crater. A puddle pools. The snake wraps around a young tree. It sprouts from an old stump—massive, long dead—with roots that circle the world. 
Wolf observes. Apples swerve to spare him. She stirs. The serpent dries into bark. Wolf becomes stardust, fades, and gifts the space with his being. 
She awakens, alone, clutching her purse. It’s open. Something sparkles. She looks inside. It’s her meteor. Dazzled, she grasps the stone. It splits in two. She lifts a lobe. Down falls a chain, fine as thread, seven metal links: Gold, Silver, Iron, Mercury, Bronze, Copper and a hook of lead. 
She puts on the earrings, looks in the water, and sees her reflection—ruby lips and sparkling eyes, beautiful as the starry sky. Beneath the surface, beneath the image of her starlight earrings, her feet glow like coals, bright as a furnace. 
The water sizzles. 
Steam billows. 
Rainbows flare. 
The steam subsides, like a veil, revealing her heels of meteor steel: quenched, cooled, dark, silvered. 
Venus, jewel of the solar corona, crests the horizon. Sun follows. Its beam parts the sea, threads a cave and climbs a mountain. The base, lead, is topped by a belt of copper, then slopes of tin, mercurial crags, rusty rocks, sliver clouds and a golden capstone. It shines like the sun. 
Jaq pinches herself. Nothing. She looks around, then down at her heels. She clicks them three times. Embarrassed, nothing, she tries again. 
There’s no place like home.
Jaq jumps, looks around. “Who’s there!?”
I think you’re supposed to say, “There’s no place like home.”
“Where are you?”
Did you steel a book?
Jaq looks in her bag—no book. “How did you know?”
I am that book.
Jaq sits, out of focus. “The Story Atlas?”
Story Atlas.
“Atlas… Can you help me?”
I don’t know. 
“My sister. She has to be here, I have to rescue her.”
Did you read the book?
“I flipped through it.”
Do you know what it’s about?
“Story Structures? Myths?”
And transformation. I recognize this place.
“Where are we?”
Not where.
Jaq thinks. 
Golden apples on a golden island at sunset? Are you disoriented and overwhelmed—like you’ve been swallowed by a whale?
“You could say that.” Jaq remembers the jaws becoming a cave. She remembers the earth swallowing her. 
This world appears to be drawn from my pages.
“What do you mean?”
I recognize too much. It’s like my diagrams were used as blueprints to make this space. It’s not normal, for the second, minute and hour hand to tick though time aligned—for a journey through day, night, month and year to happen at the same time. But what do you see?
She scans the area, confused. 
Golden apples, falling, beneath the horizon, with an upside down sunset, under a waning half moon? As you enter a new world? It’s all too perfect—it’s too aligned—even for a story. 
“What does that mean?”
It means: The space we are in is time. 
The sun approaches. Beneath, the golden sand begins to quiver, to vibrate, into yellow bricks, into a road. Zombies crown the horizon. They dance down the path—towards the island. 
“Do you know where my sister would be?”
If we are in a story, I am clearly your guide. I do not, however, know where she is.
“Then how can you help me?”
If this place is based on my blueprints, I can tell you the when of where we are, and I can tell you the myths in what you see. 
“Okaayyy. Are you a genie, do I need to rub the earring and make a command?”
I’m not in the earrings, or heals. I’m in their space. And you don’t have to speak out loud. I can hear your silent questions.
Jaq thinks the question, a little bratty, a little stilted, Oh great and powerful Atlas, meta-temporal wizard, whilst thou define, whenst we are art in this temporeality? 
We stand at the crossroads of day and the night sky, summer and winter, wake and dream, life and death. This is the other side of sunset, the fall equinox, the mouth of Hell, Hades and the Duat. Behind was a calling, ahead is initiation. The where of this now is a golden island of sunset—a hole in the horizon—a threshold crossing.
Threshold crossing? Like The Threshold of Adventure?
The term used by Joseph Campbell to describe this stage in the hero’s journey, a stage unveiled by Rudolf Steiner, in ways of initiation. This is when we are swallowed, into the belly, into the nightsea journey. This is when we leave our world to go somewhere new, when the hero, as a beast of burden to an inherited morality, enters the desert to prove his value—to become a lion. Did you come through a wardrobe or rabbit hole, over a rainbow or through a mirror? Did you set with the sun. Were you planted with seeds? Did you see Sky making love with Earth. You would call it storm.
chapters.forge:

She crumbles to a rock—to a standing stone. 
Anteros sighs, then thinks to himself, I would do anything. The surge of urgency lurches him forward into a senseless march. His thumb snags, immediately, on a thorn of lifeless rose. Blood drips, into the snow. He watches, and falls, into a trance. 

In a garden, surrounded by green, Jaq looks forward, still. Cupid sits beside her. “Welcome, Jaq-of-the-Green. Your sacrifice has brought you here, for a lesson earned by letting go. It felt heroic, didn’t it, to slay your dragon?” 
“Yeah.”
“The heroic ego had to die, for you to get here. It was angry, wasn’t it?”
Empty, “Yes.” 
“So offended, so righteous, so blind.” 
She looks down, ashamed. 
“And now?”
“I feel defeated.”
“What feels defeated?” Space opens. “What lost can’t win. Why did you drink the mettle?”
“I was pissed.”
“About what.”
“That I let him make me what I was.” She looks at him. “For letting him split me in pieces—for letting him teach me to hate myself.” 
“You hated him.” 
“I hated myself.” 
“Good.” She is surprised at what she said. “And now?”
“I want it all back! I want to be all of me. I missed it. I felt terrible. I felt emotionless. I didn’t care about power or purity or anything like that. I just wanted to be with myself. I just wanted to be whole. I just wanted to be me.” 
“What you did was very special. We are in awe. We felt that with you, and it changed us. But there’s more to what you did—to how you reshaped the dream. You are who knew what to do, but you don’t know what you did. You don’t know yourself. When you drank in yourself and all you had othered, how did it feel?”
“Like everything—all at once.” 
“And then?” 
From deep stillness, “I was extinguished—I am extinguished.” 
Cupid nods. “It’s time for a magic question.” Leafs lift in the breeze, showing their blue. “Do you feel less like you, less yourself, when you’re quiet, when you’re empty, when you’re still?”
Tears flow. “No.” She sobs. “I feel.” She can’t speak. “Like I’m all here.” 
“You are meant to remember this. You have been quenched, like hot steel, in a field of awareness. What you are experiencing is not particularity. This is presence.” Her breath clears with passing emotion. Vitality comes with the breeze, through damp lashes, awakening her vibrant eyes.  
“Do you remember the pool table?”
“Yes”
“Remember the pool table. We have to go back there. You did not fully escape. Shadow saved you from learning. Can you see it in your mind?” She sees the table. 
Imagine a musical instrument inside each ball. A French horn, a drumstick, a guitar—in amber—they’re racked. 
Now, imagine, whenever a ball is touched, whenever it would clack, it makes the sound of the instrument. Return to the game. Now listen.
She watches as BB breaks and hears the instruments—a chord, a sequence of notes. The secret is not in the table. It’s in the sound. No matter how many sounds or instruments you hear, your eardrum, like a microphone, vibrates with a single vibration. This vibration is all the vibrations of all the instruments. 
The spiritual journey and philosophical quest is motivated by estrangement and separateness— from god, lover, cosmos, humanity, or anything we hope to be one with. The journey of understanding is from a perception of the world as particularized and isolated to a vision of togetherness. This is a journey to elixir. Mythic elixirs throughout the world and across time carry the secret of waves. 
The song of cicadas arrives like the tide. A frog rabbets. An owl whos. The breeze comes through. “When you hear the frog, when you hear the cicada, you hear one sound—one wave. When you hear all the waves of all the notes of all the instruments in a symphony, you hear one wave. Waves can be one and many. 
“And we are waves.”
All of us. 
“One sound.”
And many sounds.
“Nothing is separate—not sand, stone or particle.” 
Yet everything is individual. 
“I drank it in.” 
You drank it in. 
She feels the hum of oneness. 
‘You are ready. Look directly ahead.”
She looks directly ahead. “Let your eyes rest where they want to rest. Pick a point. Settle your gaze. Only look at this point. Your eyes will dart and change focus. You will blink. That has to be okay. When this happens, when you feel the impulse to dart, dart back to the spot. When you feel the instinct to refocus, refocus on the spot. These blinks will matter less and less, until it gets easy. I will help.”
Jaq is settled, still, her eyes hooded, fixed. 
“Forget about your breathing, just focus on the spot. What happens when a human is still? It’s important to know. Let the letting go. Be still and grow.” 
The world blossoms from her center—continuously kaleidoscoping into living geometry, into glowing gems, into Visionary Experience. Time passes.
“What do you see?”
“I never knew I was in. I never knew I did not know I was—I am—in.” 
“And now, do you feel in?”
Jaq fountains, “and of, and with.”
“With what?”
Her face twists. She sobs—sorry for decades of self-absorbed exile. 
“Life.” 
Her struggle fades into a sense of overwhelming alrightness. Her fight, fear and anger let go.
“This is why you’re here, Jaq. This is what you came to learn—to get and to give. You are alive! It’s all alive! Too afraid to look, too afraid it wouldn’t be there, life has been hidden, behind walls of the mind. Nature has been reduced to resource, for a people that would leave. Progress thinks it will kill nature, someday. It expects to transcend. It cannot. This long arc away from nature, through all of human history, has come to a turning point, and to make this turn, you need old weapons.”
“Like the sword?”
“Why do you think the book was unfinished?”
“Because the writer stopped writing?”
“He is writing. And he is here, with you, learning what you are learning.”
Jaq is stunned. So is the writer. “What is he writing?”
“Has Atlas spoken of meteor steel?” She thinks for a moment. The answer is no. “Then why are your earrings starlight? Why are your heels steel? What is this place, Jaq? What is the book? What’s missing in here is missed out there. Life brought you in, to this world of imagination, to heal in its own language. Life brought him here, with you, to rewrite the book—to reveal the weapon kept secret through time, to identify the flying object. 
“Your myth has been long arriving, through stories moved by your incubation. What happened here is happening around the world. Teams of people, plants and animals, mushrooms are working to share the secret: life. 
A trickle, a dam-burst, a movement. It’s coming. It’s inevitable—a return journey to nature. If life can be seen in the leaves, if church can be seen in the trees, when the book of life is seen as a book of poetry, the conditions will clear for something new.” 
She looks around the garden. “You climbed Mt. Isolation. It didn’t used to be like that.”
“I thought if I drank in my other, as the protagonist, so would Pan, as the world.”
“You have re-identified with all you are. Pan cannot—not until the mountain erupts. Body is forgotten as temple. Earth is forgotten as womb. The patterns of life have been miss-taken as prisons. Free thought has been pushed to the periphery. Transcendence has broken the wisdom of wholeness. Life must be reclaimed as a book of poetry”
“What am I supposed to do?”
“The prison is cracked. It will burst, and reform, to its natural flow. Stay focused, stay aligned. You will know what to do.”

Obsidian roots twinkle with starlight—like a Christmas tree. A stone circle surrounds the center. Feet dance and stomp in the soggy ground. Mud rises to their ankles. Roots begin to sweat and stream. A puddle pools. In panic, they flee the center.
A curious dancer turns back. She returns to the fountain and looks at the surface. Through her reflection, she sees the obsidian tree. Mummies swing from its branches. 
More dancers come look, then all of them. They see themselves dangling—in the water, in the tree. Silver cords appear, like umbilicals, connecting them to their reflections. Eros nods. They enter themselves.

The Obsidian Throne Room is flooding. Glowing veins of the great tree, amber, light the mountain’s core. A honeycomb lattice is revealed. This space is contrived. 
Bees descend the column, through obsidian branches. Buzz against glass restores black to bark. Like halos, they swarm the heads of precious dead. Silver threads weave round the mummies, until they glow, until the dancers burst free—like moths from cocoons. 
Dirt becomes mud becomes puddles. Jaq lies by the empty cup. Her earrings have returned. They glow like meteor seeds. Her heels sizzle and quench in the flooding ground. She lies still. Steam rises. Rainbows flare. 
Blood drops past Echo, like a tear from another world, onto Jaq’s left eyelid. Her eyes shoot open. Her sister roars with the pain of labor. 

Jaq’s heels ground firmly in the living soil. She looks up at her sister. The voice of Obsidian echoes, “you will never escape.” A flood of bees swarms the space. Jaq takes her sister. “You have nowhere to go.”
A radical first root sprouts beneath the vessel. A beetle flies free. She follows the clue. She peers in the bowl’s reflection—of the mountain above, of its upside-down hologram. She steps in. Bees follow, then the dancers. Flood closes in. The mountain rumbles.

chapters.integration:
Atop the Golden Summit, green shoots of will-be narcissus grow from Jaq’s sparkling heels. Bees flee from the chasm below. She cradles her sister and observes the familiar scene: Ra’s broken throne, the cratered pantheon, a path of golden scales—dead, dry. The hum of bees against mail lifts up the snakeskin. It sloughs from the path, revealing bricks of packed sand, vibrating sand, vibrating amber. It flows~like a river of honey. 
The mountain quakes and turns inside out—into a hollow cone. The ground towers overhead, and the honey thread, of Zoe, the clue, streams upward, through the lunar mirror. She sees the planets—churning—in its frame, and calls Atlas. “Are you there?” 
In a way.
What do you mean?
Something is different. I think I am being rewritten.
The mountain prepares to blow. A honeycomb drift takes shape beneath her. The volcano explodes with magmic water. She flows to the mirror, on a wave of honey. Her craft vibrates and grows into a golden cup-boat. Bees follow her through the looking glass, back to the…
Cosmic Road. Bees take form around her. Nectar flares and flows from the solar corona. Ahead, the planets are aligned, like a thread of pearls—each in a state of mutation. When are we. 
The road back, the magic flight, when the radical first root grows into a network, when the world prepares to sprout with coming spring. This is when team is regathered, resolution begins and authorship is claimed. 

The New Moon cracks, like a black mirror, by a radical sliver of light. The lunar surface begins to fold and resolve into dead-white brain coral, into a labyrinth of mirrors. In the reflections, she sees Obsidian’s face. 
 “You have nowhere to go,” he says, then folds out of view. “You set me free-to be nothing—to be the everywhere you can never escape.”
Black as the cars on Mars, UFO’s take formation behind them. She accelerates to the red planet. A figure appears in the distance. “What’s that?” 
It swoops through the bees between her: It’s Sisyphus, in winged sandals. The bees become starlight. He joins Jaq. “You did it.”
“Did what.”
“Broke my curse.” They jerk to new speeds. ”Now, let’s get you out of here. They still want your starlight.” 

Mars approaches—the UFO’s give chase. The planet’s surface—volcanic and explosive—is bombarded with meteors. “Everything is in transformation. Ares is responding with courage.” 
UFO’s close in. Panic grips Jaq. “How do we shake them?” 
He looks back. There’s nothing there. “I don’t see anything.” She looks back. The saucers are darker and more demonic. 
“You don’t see the demons?” 
Abandon fear and terror, and you will recognize what appears as your mind’s projection.
“The language of this place is a virus of self imprisonment.”
Jaq exhales, releasing a venomous heat from her lungs, and looks back. All that’s there is where she’s been. She looks at her sister, struggling, but alive. 
This is when to remember how far you’ve come. How much you’ve learned. How much you’ve grown. This is when your heart opens and flies, back, from the great below. This is when, in a whole new way, you start to know, you can do it.
“When you drank the mettles, your mettles, you forged a connection with the planets. The way up was a curse. The way back must be a cure. You must be the cure. 
Her focus renews. Her calm is restored, as she transits Cygnus—the Swan stars. Her eyes glow like the planet of steel. “If you want life to see you, see what life sees.”
Balls of flaming tar, garbage, falling satellites, needles, empty spirit bottles, mix in with the meteors.  
“He didn’t expect it, when he let it in—everything he refused to see—but it’s making him stronger, more whole, more grounded, more real. If this place can transform, if the heart of Pan can be healed, it must be healed with immunities—to dead matter and purification”

Mercury comes into view. The surface flows with liquid metal. A web of chains that span the cosmos, squeezes tight. Jaq is herself. She sees winged sandals on Sisyphus’ feet. “Greed, ancient greed, exhales from the heart of Hermes. He flows like quicksilver. His ancient coffers erupt with charity. His chains resist.”

Jaq settles, closes her eyes, and channels Mercury. They open—liquid grey. “Light as a feather, happy as an angel, merry as a schoolboy, giddy as a loosened man.” 
The planet pulses, with a massive heartbeat. Its chains flow, like cleared veins. It beats again. Jaq’s eyes restore. They flow towards…

Jupiter, and look down on the planet. It storms fiercely. At the center of its eye, lightning strikes. “Thrones crumble like thunder as Zeus remembers. His rise was for freedom—was for everyone.”
Jaq’s eyes crackle with lightning. “Fall in love with life again.” Digesting, the planet rumbles. Echo screams with pains of labor—still unconscious, still in bandages.

Venus nears. A shadow cuts horns in the copper planet. The crescent brightens as they wane sharp. Sisyphus reports, “Love erupts through rinds of pleasure. Venus is in the heavens, again, but not chaste from mater. She recognizes everyone. She co-experiences with everything. If she can restore her eyes, she will be restored as the goddess.” Venus blackens with shadow. 
A new crescent, new light, horns of plenty, grow from Venus to illuminate Jaq’s bowl of wax. Jaq’s eyes glow, copper, like the goddess. “To see in full beauty, know life. You will find life knows you.” 

Saturn. The train of many metals has deconstructed. Cars orbit and swerve, trackless, chaotic, autonomous, around Cronos. The titan meditates, quiet as lead, in the inner core of his planet. 
“Saturn is in his sphere of solitude. Sloth transforms, through meditation, into mysticism. Stillness, fixedness, opens space for flow. Titanic surrender to the unknown, submission of control, restores balance, clarity and the capacity for Self-authorship.” 
As they near, she sees Saturn, eyes closed, in every train, steering, like charioteers without hands. Headlights shine on Jaq’s face. An engine speeds past and elongates into a beam. A new car, Uranium, shines green like a little sun. It breaks away, towards…
Uranus blips into being. It radiates static. They come into focus. The planet pixelates, kaleidoscopes and takes cymatic form. Jaq is struck with awe and wonder. 
“Magic is not fantasy! And he has always been here.”
“Who?”
“Uranus, Prometheus…”
Her eyes go radioactive. She channels the planet. ”The writer writes of cymatic bees, meteor steel and elixir waves.”
“You can feel it can’t you?”
“Like I feel the planets.”
“It’s new to me too.”
Her connection deepens. “He didn’t put down the book, to put down a weapon. He put down his obstacle—to self and creation.” But, he didn’t abandon you. He didn’t throw you away or put you down. He couldn’t. So he brought you here, to give you life so he could survive. “If there is anything you’d like to say, he’s hear.” 
Oh.
Echo is at peace, for the moment. 
I would say, I’m sorry, for the thousand nights, for the fixation on my birth, for time he gave me and not to his people. I’m sorry for the sacrifice, and the warps in life that taught him to see me. For warps so big he could show me to others. I’m sorry for Leela’s coma, and her struggle for rebirth, on the spring equinox, on the full moon, on the third day. I can’t say the other thing. He knows what it is. I feel responsible.

He know’s it was not your fault. You were not a bad complex. You were The complex, for him—the one he signed up for, like a fool, but with his heart. He does not want your guilt. And he does not see you, as Maya—not anymore. He believes in your original purpose—that you can be a secret weapon, a great equalizer, for a thousand stories, for a thousand revolutions, in a thousand hearts, and a thousand worlds. He just needed the missing stone, and he couldn’t find it by himself… She stops. Tears stream from her face. “He needed me.”

Is he writing you? 

She pauses, listens, feels. “No.”

When this is over, will I just be an Atlas? 

No. That’s not what he sees. People will talk to you and ask you questions, about their journeys, about life, as I have. You will be precious. You are precious. You just needed a story to find your soul. 

Her eyes are restored to normal. They come alongside the train car. Its golden wheels draw their attention. 

My blue prints.

“You recognize them?”

The wheels go round. Yes, and look, they are synchronized, like little fractals, of our journey. 

“Do you recognize them all?”

A rear wheel struggles, trailing sparks behind the train car. A golden hubcap gives way, revealing a rim of meteor steel. 

All but one. 

They leave Uranus behind them. A blue marble comes into focus:


Earth. “And now you know the mountain’s truth: its base is earth and always will be—the top I’ve never seen.” They ascend the inverted mountain—towards its peak, the foothills. Water fills the world behind, chasing them up the summit. 

Earth rises in her eye’s reflection. “There’s no place like home.” As they reach the top, the world flips downside up. They stand at the base of the mountain. Water cascades like an avalanche. 
She sees the cave-mouth—overtaken by tree stars. Everywhere, the ground turns under, transforming, as though tilled. Life bursts through, quaking, steaming, titanic, chthonic. They enter…

Plato’s Cave. Jaq approaches the billiard table. She observes, then leans—over the surface. “Eeeeeeeehhhhhhyyyyyyyaaaaaaaaahhhhhhhweeeeehhhhhhhhh.” The table begins to ripple, like water, to the sound. She repeats the chant, “eeeeeeeehhhhhhhyyyyyyaaaaaaaaahhhhhhwwwweeeehhhhhh.” The surface becomes water, the balls become whirlpools. Bees buzz the table. It awakens with cymatic patterns. Light glimmers in the swirling water—like starlight brushstrokes. 
BB begins to vibrate and hum. Jaq kisses his forehead. As her field nears his, he turns to sea blue water, storms, whirlpools and waves— then flesh, his whole body. She smiles at him, making eye contact, and continues. His eyes weep like a tired fountain. He kneels, exhales. A hand reaches down. It’s Sisyphus. 
He gets up and follows the brawny man. BB draws a whirlpool from the table: an 8 ball in his hand, alive with vibration. He throws it—into the cave. It pings off chains and locks, freeing prisoners. 
Sisyphus shoulders the pool table. BB joins him. They both vex. It is a massive boulder. They try to roll it, down the hill. It resists. They put their backs into it. Crack, thunder, it breaks free. The table spills its balls, out, into the buzzing cave. 
Chaos. Efficiency. Chains are broken, headsets shattered. No one is getting hurt. Bees buzz around them. Headsets vibrate—into pixie dust. The bees disappear as people awaken. Golden ties turn black as stingers. BB breaks chains with his cue. Wakened dreamers exodus. 
Kedalion sits on Jaq’s shoulder, starlight. She does not see.
The Yellow Brick Road is buzzing to pieces. Jaq spills from the cave. Kedalion fades, into sunshine. The scarf returns to her shoulders. She feels the wool and sighs. 
A path of honey leads to the island. Bees fly over the wasted sand, awakening patterns—mandalas—of nectar. The voice of Obsidian bellows overhead, “You will never leave this house.”
 Jaq queries Atlas, do you know the way out?
Through.
Green growth springs from her chosen steps. Bees, dancers, animals—water rises, like walls, on a path that parts the sea. 

The Golden Island takes them in. Waves zip closed behind. The world encircling serpent unwraps from his tree—alive but not yet budding. Wolf has been waiting. “Are you ready to arrive?”
“I am ready to return! Who are you?”
“This island is liminal. It lives and dies at the limits—between this prison and the world story.” 
“What are You?”
“I am Wolf. I watch. I am Storm. I am the lightning-bolt. I am here because I want you to win. You have done well. Life believes in you. You still don’t believe in your life. After everything, you are still full of doubt. Doubt got you here. It won’t get you home.” She starts to speak. He raises his paw. “The boatman will take you.” 
Set arrives in a glowing ark—in a living tree—its roots woven into a hull, its branches woven into a sail, and its great mast, a great trunk, strung with flowing vines.
“Movement is trying to happen. Obstructions, of the mind, are giving way. There are many efforts to save life on this planet. They will all fall short without an awakening—to nature as church and life as Bible, to the poetry, to the ceremony, to the living revelation. Until life is seen in the leaf, until the forest is known as cathedral, the effort to save your shelter, will prove too weak.” 
The deck is full: doves, rabbits, harrowed dancers, deer and buffalo, black and white rams, ravens, serpents, cats, lions and crocodile, camels and elephants, the friendly dog, Leela, no longer a cyborg. 
Jaq leaps and flies to the crow’s nest. Her earrings shine, like a light house on a pirate ship. The sea rises and lifts them up. She hears the voice of Wolf. 


You have destroyed the lesser prison of dead matter. You have disrupted and erupted the greater prison of purification. You have learned to see life as poetry, and opened the eye of your heart. This is your strength.
The dragon beneath them glows, and the island comes to life. The way up is like the way down, only new: seeds in coffins—now sprouting, the double slit, the chasm, whale and spout, the maelstrom, the black. 
What has happened here will ripple into the world, with new understanding. A radical change in direction is in potential. A world free of prisons can be born, from life. Meek can inherit the earth, we can remember, all are indigenous to this world, or we can forget, rebuild the prisons, and start it all over—bigger, better and for less prepared heroes. No Jaq, it would cost too much. It has to end this time. 
This world wants to heal, and it’s already started. Shadow has fled to the world above. He will seek to weave a new web. You cannot let that happen. When you escape, you must stop him. You must free the imagination. You have roared the Royal No, in here. How will it sound out there? When you do what’s right, solidarity you could never imagine will be there to meet you. 
Money and power cannot do what you can do. It’s up to you, and if you fall into the gravity of their stories, you will be lost, with all your hope, to the streams of momentum. No. It’s on you—to lead those who can lead themselves—not with rules, not with examples, but with connection. Inspire. Think for yourself, and they, like you, might lead themselves out. Those who do will be a force. A free imagination, an imagination in touch with life, is powerful, and dangerous.”
The seas continue to rise, accelerating, carrying them towards the pole star, to Polaris, through a sixteen-petaled tunnel of blue light. Set lifts his Adze to the Little Dipper. 
The lack of education will shock you. Wisdom must be shared, and preserved, for those who will seek it, for those who will bring it ever into our world. The future is in those who can meet nature—who can heal their break with life. Like arks in a flood, they will survive the crisis of spirit. They will help remember and remind how to see, poetically. Your journey does not end with your return.
The pass through the pole star. The tunnel closes, until there is nothing but light. 
This is when you sprout.
chapters.drawing:
It’s twilight outside the Mythouse. Walls teem with ivy. Anteros and Nin sleep in his car. They startle awake—eyes open like rising half moons. 
The gates are sealed with a golden chain. He has bolt cutters. They won’t cut. He shoulders the hold. Nothing. Tree stars burst through cracks in stone.
In the Mythouse Garden, in the shell-stone well, Jaq holds Echo. The well fountains and overflows with foam. Bees burst from below and swarm the lifeless garden. Their vibrations hook leaves of linden and buds of oak with faerie kisses of green life. They do not catch. Life does not spread. The bees gather into dancers—hundreds. The space is in conflict between life and lifelessness. Their dancing tries to heal the grotto. 
Obsidian watches, angry, in a cloud of incoherent, incomplete incarnation. 
Echo labors with pangs of birth. Jaq steps from the well, her heels and earrings gleaming, and lays down her sister.
Like a conductor, a Bokur, Obsidian lifts his arm. He tries to reclaim the zombies. Dancers fight his familiar movements—the lifeless embodiment of his will. A woman seizes and falls, then another, then all of them. Their skin and hair dies, and hardens, into keratin cocoons. “You’re all dead! It’s all dead! You don’t believe in love. You don’t believe in life! You think you experienced something?! In that dream? In that hallucination?”
Her heels and earrings dim. They disappear. Her purse returns to her shoulder. “It was all wish fulfillment! Fantasy! And where does that come from? Your corruption is your craving, and it was all craving. It was all corruption. You are corruption—pure wish fulfillment. Now give me my starlight, and fade, back, into obscurity, where you belong.” 
She opens her purse. The book glints. Its cover reads: Revelation of Fallen Starlight. She finds the meteor and draws it from her purse.
He’s becoming fanatical. “You are impure, unclean, unfaithful and made of sin. You are a broken woman. I will not let you infect the world with your curses. There will be no more Eve, no more Pandora, no more Jaq! I know your sins, and they will destroy your message. They will cancel you, like a criminal, like a foreigner, like a minority. They will make you homeless. The world will turn on you, and I will see that it does. Corruption gives way to corruption.” 
Jaq looks around. Dancing bodies writhe. Trees struggle between green and grey. Echo screams a contraction. 
Jaq looks at him, “Oh Yeah?” She slings the stone at his forehead: nothing. The secret weapon falls, into his hands, then transforms, into a sword of starlight. His cloud of shadow solidifies. 
Obsidian looks at the blade, proud, and sees his reflection, then Shadow, then BB. A storm swirls around him. He despairs. “No!” Ra, Moon, Mars, Mercury. He sees his face transform: Jupiter. Venus, Saturn. 
Echo screams a final push. “Matter is not dead or impure, it’s alive.”
Her sister opens her eyes, aware. Everyone is struggling—with the will of Obsidian. Jaq is in awe. She watches as Echo stands and moves to the center. Obsidian glows, red, orange, yellow, blue, purple—struggling with himself. 
Echo looks at her sister, and feels her way in. She lets the tethers of pain and fear that grip the space grip firm to her. She settles, lowers, exhales, and grips back. She breaths in. Her bare heels square with the ground, she begins a new dance. 
Graceful gestures draw notes of clarity through a sea of sound. Violent tosses, and turns, within the chrysalis, soften, into rhythmic movement. The shells themselves begin to vibrate, and resolve, into colorful mummies. Sublime, Echo swells, with her heart, to hold the space, then brings them in—one by one—to the dance. Change is happening. She breathes with the leaves, she stomps with the earth. Like fire, she cuts the space. Like water, she brings it together. Green comes. 
Locked in his own reflection, Obsidian fights Shadow, until it grows, in every direction, like grape vines, into the secret garden. 
“You cannot control what we see and believe—not anymore. You have no control—not over me, not over LIFE. And if you cannot kill me, if you cannot steal life from my imagination, you cannot play dead!” 
Mummies stand. Wrappings fall as they join the dance. In their own space, in the shared space, they move together, one and many, aware. 
As the garden transforms and greens, the mansion begins to crack. A mound swells from below, until the brick walls crumble, until they begin to circulate—like a volcano becoming a doughnut becoming a mound—a comfortable home in the ground, with a perfectly round door, a porthole painted green, with a shiny yellow brass knob, in the exact middle. 
“I know what’s in your heart. I have met your fractured pieces.”
Grey loses the garden. Obsidian cools—black, empty, stunned—reflecting the leaves like verdant scales. 
“I have shared your life!” 
Green sprouts from his surface and begins to grow. 
Kedalion, from the back of the sharpened meteor, on the shoulder of Sisyphus, waves at Jaq. She laughs tears of awe and touches her heart. 
Obsidian sees Eros in the blade. His grit fades with the steely eyes of love denied. Connection flows, until arrives, Pan of a thousand faces. 
Trees stars erupt from the sword. It falls to the ground—reclaimed by sound and a sea of green. 
Dancers dance. Life flows. Without obstruction, the garden grows.
chapters.new-age:
Immersed in the dancing space, Jaq, still, looks in the eyes of Pan, knows Eros, feels Sisyphus, sees Kedalion. They look back. 
“What will happen now?”
“What happened here will happen everywhere. A new story will begin.”
“What will happen to this place”
“The one who made it will return.”

Jaq looks at Echo. Moths flutter free from her wrappings. Jaq—overwhelmed with joy—rushes to greet her sister. Overflowing, she squeezes Echo, like she’ll never let her go. Echo blinks, her lashes like newborn wings, and sees her sister deeply. Jaq brushes away the bandages, like leaves from a season past. She parts the threads on her face, like wisps of an angel’s hair—and sees with her heart:
 Echo has given birth to herself. A falcon cries. The chrysalis-chests of a thousand dancers, erupt, in masse, with butterflies.

Outside the garden, the golden chains, on the door, diffuse into sunlight. Anteros bursts through…  
Into the garden. Pan is gone. Echo sees and laughs, at ease. Time slows for Jaq as she turns. 
He stands at the opening, with Nin—his hair lit by the rising sun. Tired, filthy, dedicated, tool in hand, he sees her, and knows. 
Understanding, acceptance, love, joy, sorrow and heartbreak, she comes to him. They embrace, as though taking a long-needed sip of cool water. 
“I love you,” she says. 
“I know.” 

“I can’t,” she says. 

“I know.”

“Not right now.” 

He sighs a sigh and lets her go. “You are so big. I see it. I feel it. And I love you. And I want you to be big. And it’s not that I would keep you small...” 
“I know.”
He cries. “But you have to go, somewhere, and it’s not with me.” She kisses him, passionately, really passionately. She gives him her light. She gives him her darkness. He’s there with all that she is, enraptured, accepted, with all of his generosity and all of his gratitude. As the moment peaks, we feel it end. 
They draw back to let go, but knowing they know what it will mean, they draw in again, and kiss through tears, alive, wildly alive, until they can’t, until they stop, exhale, and release. It’s over. It’s sad—and okay.

The young Tycoon taps her shoulder. The huddle loosens. “I think this is yours.” He opens his hand: it’s the meteor. He gives it freely. She receives the starlight as hers. A lyre plays. It’s the soldier. He sings a honey song. 
A finale of dancers leaves through the gate. The once-lifeless woman, from the studio floor, looks back—grateful, gleeful, awed, alive, surrounded by a doorway wreathed in tree stars. Jaq winks. The woman smiles and skips on. 
Jaq puts the cornerstone in her purse and looks to her friends. They look at each other and join arms. “Are you ready?” They nod, smile and return—at home in the world.
